results.title: La Sel de la terre
results.creator_credit: Georges Rouquier, V. Blavier and Intermondia Films
results.brief_description: Lyrical impression of the Camargue county at the mouth of the Rhone - long, flat reaches of salt impregnated land, rich in bird and animal life. The latter sequences deal with the draining of the land its fertilization and bringing it into production. Sparse commentary in French.

results.title: La scalo lo scalone
results.brief_description: A child born to Italian parents in country Victoria learns about his growing sexuality. In innocence he and his friends play the usual child games of Doctors and Nurses as a natural means of learning. His play is fettered by religious guilt (that he’s yet to understand) and further complicated my his mother’s sudden death. A story about the loss of innocence - both as a state of mind and a time in one’s life that will never be the same again.

results.title: La Rupture = The Breakup
results.creator_credit: Claude Chabrol, Cinevog Films, Les Films de la Boetie and Euro International
results.brief_description:
A wife and mother, Helene, battles to defend herself and her child against an attack by her husband Charles while he is under the influence of LSD. With his son in hospital her father-in-law moves to gain custody of the child by employing the needy Paul to spy on Helene in order to find cause. This is the fourth of Chabrol’s series of thrillers set in bourgeois households, usually involving a triangle, that began with ‘Les Biches’ (1968). It also involves a further variant on the redemption-through-the-assumption-of-guilt theme recurring in Chabrol’s films, which he found, as a critic, recurring in Hitchcock’s work. Also available on VHS.

Credits: Director, [script], Claude Chabrol ; photography, Jean Rabier ; music, Pierre Jansen ; editor, Jacques Gaillard ; sound, Guy Chichignoud.
Cast: Stephane Audran, Jean-Pierre Cassel, Michel Bouquet, Annie Cordy, Jean-Claude Drouot, Michel Duchaussoy.

Note: Based on the novel by Charlotte Armstrong “Le jour des parques”.

results.title: La Ronde = Circle of love
results.creator_credit: Roger Vadim, Raymond Hakim and Robert Hakim
results.brief_description: La Ronde is a romantic drama with an all-star cast lead by Jane Fonda, Jean Sorel and Catherine Spaak. It is set in pre-World War I Paris when the city was caught in a fever pitch of gaiety and affairs of the heart. Based on Arthur Schintzler’s famous stage play “Reigen”, the screenplay is given a fresh viewpoint by applying French psychology to the pursuit of love in its various forms. Dubbed in English.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roger Vadim, Raymond Hakim and Robert Hakim

images.caption: La Ronde = Circle of love (Roger Vadim) still

results.title: La Ronde
results.brief_description: An ironic narrator comperes Ophuls’ circular tale of love and seduction set in the nostalgic Vienna of 1900. “La Ronde” was booed at its premiere, but went on to become one of the greatest successes of post-war European cinema. Bans and protests againsts its ‘immorality’ only boosted its fame: in London it played for eighteen months at one cinema. With a superb cast, lavish production values and bravura camerawork, “La Ronde” confirms Ophuls’ reputation as one of the cinema’s major artists. Stars a veritable who’s who of European cinema including Anton Walbrook, Simone Signoret, Serge Reggiani, Simone Simon, Daniel Gelin, Danielle Darrieux, Fernand Gravey, Odette Joyeux, Jean-Louis Barrault, Isa Miranda and Gerard Philipe.

results.title: La Revolution Francaise = the French Revolution
results.brief_description:
Episode 22 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
A fourty minute overview of the events spanning from the storming of La Bastille to the irresistible ascent of Bonaparte. Reference: Encyclopedia Britannica.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: La Regle du jeu = Rules of the game
results.creator_credit: Jean Renoir, Claude Renoir and Nouvelle Edition Francaise
results.brief_description:
Renoir’s portrayal of a weekend house party in the country is, in effect, the portrayal of a society in crisis, a social world in which there are rules but no values. On the surface the film is a comedy of manners based on the tradition of 18th century French theatre. Its richness lies in the contrast between ambiguity and clarity, the elaborate parallelisms between groups and specific characters and a pathbreaking melange of stylistic techniques. Renoir ironically exposes the moral bankruptcy of this world while remaining consistent with the model of classical theatre in his deployment of closure. The film’s influence lies in Renoir’s modernism. In portraying life-as-flux he juxtaposes what in his hands are formal devices for openness (mobile camera, depth of field, use of off-screen space) with the closure of classical narrative implied by, for example, shot-counter-shot editing. Also available on VHS and LD.

Credits: Director, Jean Renoir ; producer, Claude Renoir ; photography, Jean Bachelet ; writers, Jean Renoir, Carl Koch ; music, Joseph Kosma, Roger Desormieres.
Cast: Marcel Dalio, Roland Toutain, Nora Gregor, Jean Renoir.

results.title: La Quete de Dieu
results.brief_description:
In a world almost empty of population and surrounded by the constant fear of war or invasion, small groups of people manage to erect magnificent churches. Northern Europe dominated by the heirs of Charlemagne lives the second blooming of classical Roman art. In the South, on the other side of the Loire river and the Alps, the culture and the landscapes are different. There is no central power or emmerging feudal system. The centre of power is the monastry where various experiments lead to a marked improvement in vaulting techniques. In the XIth century, religious buildings are built by paid labourers (the future guilds) but designed by clerics, “men both erudite and initiated into the mysteries. For them, considerations of perfect knowledge were to be found in numbers. And the highest human science was mathematics, closely linked to music and architecture. A romanesque church is at the same time an equation and a fugue.” Other works profiled include: the abbey of Conques (France) and the manuscripts of Gerona (Spain).

Credits: Director, Roland Darbois ; writers, Roger Stephane, Roland Darbois, photography, Roland Dantigny.
Cast: Narrated by Georges Duby.
